S5.T1.caption: Table 1: Summary of our diagnostic dataset. The pretraining, fine-tuning, and test splits contain different object/color combinations.
S5.T1.table:
Split Object/color Nb. of Nb. of
combinations images questions
Pretraining 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} 12,000 —
Training ℬℬ\mathcal{B}  3,600 3,600
Validation ℬ∪𝒞ℬ𝒞\mathcal{B}\cup\mathcal{C}    800   800
Test 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}  3,600 3,600
references:
We generate our dataset following the procedure of [5].
We render 64×64646464\!\times\!64 images with Blender [13].
Each image contains one of three objects (sphere, cube, or cylinder) in one of eight colors (red, purple, yellow, blue, green, cyan, gray, or brown).
For each object/color combination, we generate 2000 samples, randomizing the object size, material (rubber or metallic), position, and lightning.
We assign disjoint subsets of object/color combinations to the pretraining, fine-tuning, and evaluation sets, as summarized in Table 1.
The validation set contains a mix of in-domain (ID) and out-of-distribution (OOD) data, while the test set if fully OOD. The validation set serves to select hyperparameters and perform early stopping.

S5.T2.caption: Table 2: Main results (average accuracy in % ±plus-or-minus\pm one standard deviation over 3 random seeds). The baseline overfits to spurious correlations in the training data and performs poorly on the OOD validation and test sets. The EBM pretraining improves generalization, but SimCLR⋆⋆\star performs significantly better and achieves near-perfect accuracy.
S5.T2.table:
Validation Test
Overall Overall Cube only Sphere only
Baseline without visual pretraining 56.96 ±plus-or-minus\pm\,6.08 12.78 ±plus-or-minus\pm\,9.75 0.04 ±plus-or-minus\pm\,0.06 25.52 ±plus-or-minus\pm\,19.57
Baseline with supervised ImageNet pretraining 99.43 ±plus-or-minus\pm\,0.33 99.14 ±plus-or-minus\pm\,0.20 98.35 ±plus-or-minus\pm\,0.33 99.92 ±plus-or-minus\pm\,0.09
With self-supervised pretraining: EBM 93.67 ±plus-or-minus\pm\,3.18 86.74 ±plus-or-minus\pm\,8.34 96.57 ±plus-or-minus\pm\,1.99 76.91 ±plus-or-minus\pm\,14.75
With self-supervised pretraining: SimCLR⋆⋆\star 99.75 ±plus-or-minus\pm\,0.33 99.26 ±plus-or-minus\pm\,0.29 98.87 ±plus-or-minus\pm\,0.27 99.65 ±plus-or-minus\pm\,0.32
references:
We report our main results in Table 2.
We compare models built with an EBM– or CL–pretrained vision encoder, with a baseline that is not pretrained, i.e. only trained with supervision on the VQA data.
The baseline overfits to the particular object/color combinations of the VQA data and is therefore unable to generalize to the novel combinations of the validation (ID+OOD data) nor test splits (fully OOD data).
Of our pretrained models, the CL method (SimCLR⋆⋆\star) achieves the highest, near-perfect accuracy of 99.26% on the test set.
It seems to better disentangle the representations of shape from color, such that the VQA model can generalize to new combinations at test time without overfitting to the particular combinations seen during training.
EBM pretraining also improves generalization (86.74% on the test set) but with a high variance across runs (standard deviation of 8.34%).
SimCLR⋆⋆\star shows no such stability issues (standard deviation of 0.29%).

S5.T3.caption: Table 3: OOD Detection experiment. The AUROC is near-perfect (∼similar-to\sim1.0) for our EBM model on most test sets. However, it falls well below our CL model when the OOD test data is visually similar to the training (ID) data (last two columns).

Source of OOD test data
Noise CIFAR MNIST SVHN VQA v2 Background Cones
EBM ∼similar-to\sim1.00 ∼similar-to\sim1.00 ∼similar-to\sim1.00 ∼similar-to\sim1.00 ∼similar-to\sim1.00 0.52 0.30
SimCLR⋆⋆\star    0.96    0.92    0.97    0.91    0.94 0.94 0.82
references:
On five out of our seven datasets, EBMs are superior to CL (see Table 3).
They can distinguish ID from OOD data almost perfectly (AUROC of ∼similar-to\sim1.0).
However, when the OOD data is visually similar to the training data (e.g. images of backgrounds and cones), the detection performance of our EBM falls well below CL.
The estimated energies appear generally reliable for filtering out OOD samples, but they seem less able to spot fine-grained differences.
See also Figure 7 for the distributions of scores over different datasets.

S5.T4.caption: Table 4: Supervised energy-based training of a VQA model. Modified JEM correctly classifies some of the OOD samples and improves calibration over the standard classification baseline. However, its performance is still far below optimal.
S5.T4.table:
Answer accuracy (%) Calibration
Overall Spheres Cubes Cylinders ECE (%)
(Seen combinations) (OOD object/color combinations) (Lower is better)
Random guessing 33.34 33.34 33.34 33.34 —
Baseline, cross-entropy classification objective 33.34 100.00 0.00 0.00 71.54
Standard JEM [24] 29.98 99.93 0.00 0.00 71.28
Modified JEM: downscaled classification loss & early stopping 49.10 99.93 39.23 8.12 36.55
CEBM [19] 35.75 54.60 31.56 21.10 9.24
references:
The baseline model (Table 4, second row) unsurprisingly overfits the object/color combinations of the training data and is therefore unable to generalize to novel combinations at test time.
The model obtains an accuracy of 100%percent100100\% on questions about spheres (same combinations in training and test) but 0%percent00\% on cubes and cylinders (OOD combinations).
The calibration is also poor (high ECE of 71.5471.5471.54%) indicating that the model is confident about its wrong predictions.

(Table 4, third row) shows poor accuracy and calibration similar to the baseline.
Careful inspection revealed that the classification objective quickly dominates the energy learning.
In other words, the model could not simultaneously predict correct answers and be capable of generating new images.
The classification loss would typically converge much faster and, to minimize the energy loss, the model would start generating non-realistic images that always give a high energy.
The energy learning objective is thus ineffective in this regime.
We mitigate the dominance of the classification objective by down-scaling the corresponding term by a constant factor (0.1 proved effective).
The resulting model then learns to produce naturally-looking images (see Figure 8, bottom row).
Nevertheless, at some point during training, we always observed that the model would start generating noisy images that quickly diverge from the training data (see Figure 8, top row).
We solve this issue with early stopping, which we trigger when the energies of real and generated images diverge past a threshold: |E𝜽​(𝒙′)−E𝜽​(𝒙)|>0.8subscript𝐸𝜽superscript𝒙′subscript𝐸𝜽𝒙0.8|E_{{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}({\boldsymbol{x}}^{\prime})-E_{{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}({\boldsymbol{x}})|>0.8.

(Table 4, fourth row) gives a higher overall accuracy (49.10%percent49.1049.10\%) as well as a better calibration (ECE of 36.5536.5536.55%).
Contrary to the baseline, this model can therefore correctly handle some of the OOD data, although it still often confuses cubes and cylinders with relatively high confidence.
